a memo saying that`` we might be missing an opportunity'' and wondering if more troops were needed. Donald Rumsfeld alleges that he later learned a CIA agent on the ground had requested just that, but adds: I never received such a request from either Tommy Franks or Tenet. And can not imagine denying it if I had. If someone thought Osama bin Laden was cornered, as later claimed, I found it surprising that Tenet had never called me to urge Tommy Franks to support their operation. Donald Rumsfeld 's explanation?`` Their recollections may be imperfect.'' While the author goes out of his way to stress his loyalty to George W. go around. Dysfunction in decision-making arose partly because of the competing agendas of different agencies, his own included. However, he implies that ultimately it was up to President Bush to take firmer control. There were far too many hands on the steering wheel, which, in my view, was a formula for running the truck into a ditch, writes Donald Rumsfeld .
